Abstract Abstract
This document describes and discuss the text encodings of Public-Key This document describes and discuss the text encodings of Public-Key
Infrastructure using X.509 (PKIX) Certificates, PKIX Certificate Infrastructure using X.509 (PKIX) Certificates, PKIX Certificate
Revocation Lists (CRLs), PKCS #10 Certification Request Syntax, PKCS Revocation Lists (CRLs), PKCS #10 Certification Request Syntax, PKCS
#7 structures, Cryptographic Message Syntax (CMS), PKCS #8 Private- #7 structures, Cryptographic Message Syntax (CMS), PKCS #8 Private-
Key Information Syntax, and Attribute Certificates. The text Key Information Syntax, and Attribute Certificates. The text
encodings are well-known, are implemented by several applications and encodings are well-known, are implemented by several applications and
libraries, and are widely deployed. This document is intended to libraries, and are widely deployed. This document is intended to

1. Introduction 1. Introduction
Several security-related standards used on the Internet define data Several security-related standards used on the Internet define data
formats that are normally encoded using Distinguished Encoding Rules formats that are normally encoded using Distinguished Encoding Rules
(DER) [CCITT.X690.2002], which is a binary data format. This (DER) [CCITT.X690.2002], which is a binary data format. This
document is about text encodings of some of these formats: document is about text encodings of some of these formats:
1. Internet X.509 Public Key Infrastructure Certificate and 1. Internet X.509 Public Key Infrastructure Certificate and
skipping to change at page 3, line 35 skipping to change at page 3, line 35
One advantage with text encodings is that they are easy to modify One advantage with text encodings is that they are easy to modify
using common text editors; for example, a user may concatenate using common text editors; for example, a user may concatenate
several certificates to form a certificate chain with copy-and-paste several certificates to form a certificate chain with copy-and-paste
operations. operations.
The tradition within the RFC series can be traced back to PEM The tradition within the RFC series can be traced back to PEM
[RFC1421], based on a proposal by M. Rose in Message Encapsulation [RFC1421], based on a proposal by M. Rose in Message Encapsulation
[RFC0934]. Originally called "PEM encapsulation mechanism", [RFC0934]. Originally called "PEM encapsulation mechanism",
"encapsulated PEM message", or (arguably) "PEM printable encoding", "encapsulated PEM message", or (arguably) "PEM printable encoding",
today the format is sometimes referred to as "PEM encoding". today the format is sometimes referred to as "PEM encoding".
Variations include OpenPGP ASCII Armor and OpenSSH Key File Format. Variations include OpenPGP ASCII Armor [RFC2015] and OpenSSH Key File
Format [RFC4716].
For reasons that basically boil down to non-coordination (or gross For reasons that basically boil down to non-coordination or
inattention), many PKIX and CMS libraries implement a text encoding inattention, many PKIX and CMS libraries implement a text encoding
that is similar to--but not identical with--PEM encoding. This that is similar to--but not identical with--PEM encoding. This
Internet-Draft calls this format "PKIX text encoding", articulates document specifies the "PKIX text encoding" format, articulates the
the de-facto rules that most implementations operate by, and provides de-facto rules that most implementations operate by, and provides
recommendations that will promote interoperability going forward. recommendations that will promote interoperability going forward.
Peter Gutmann's X.509 Style Guide [X509SG] contains a section "base64 This document also provides common nomenclature for syntax elements,
reflecting the evolution of this de-facto standard format. Peter
Gutmann's X.509 Style Guide [X509SG] contains a section "base64
Encoding" that describes the formats and contains suggestions similar Encoding" that describes the formats and contains suggestions similar
to what is in this document. to what is in this document.
The key words "MUST", "MUST NOT", "REQUIRED", "SHALL", "SHALL NOT", The key words "MUST", "MUST NOT", "REQUIRED", "SHALL", "SHALL NOT",
"SHOULD", "SHOULD NOT", "RECOMMENDED", "NOT RECOMMENDED", "MAY", and "SHOULD", "SHOULD NOT", "RECOMMENDED", "NOT RECOMMENDED", "MAY", and
"OPTIONAL" in this document are to be interpreted as described in RFC "OPTIONAL" in this document are to be interpreted as described in RFC
2119 [RFC2119]. 2119 [RFC2119].
2. General Considerations 2. General Considerations
PKIX text encoding begins with a line starting with "-----BEGIN" and PKIX text encoding begins with a line starting with "-----BEGIN" and
ends with a line starting with "-----END". Between these lines, or ends with a line starting with "-----END". Between these lines, or
"encapsulation boundaries", are base64 [RFC4648]-encoded data. Data "encapsulation boundaries", are base64-encoded [RFC4648] data. Data
before the "-----BEGIN" and after the "-----END" encapsulation before the "-----BEGIN" and after the "-----END" encapsulation
boundaries are permitted and MUST NOT cause parsers to malfunction. boundaries are permitted and MUST NOT cause parsers to malfunction.
Furthermore, parsers MUST ignore whitespace and other non-alphabetic Furthermore, parsers MUST ignore whitespace and other non-base64
characters [DP1] and MUST handle different newline conventions. characters and MUST handle different newline conventions.
The type of data encoded is labeled depending on the type label in The type of data encoded is labeled depending on the type label in
the "-----BEGIN" line (pre-encapsulation boundary). For example, the the "-----BEGIN" line (pre-encapsulation boundary). For example, the
line may be "-----BEGIN CERTIFICATE-----" to indicate that the line may be "-----BEGIN CERTIFICATE-----" to indicate that the
content is a PKIX certificate (see further below). Generators MUST content is a PKIX certificate (see further below). Generators MUST
put the same label on the "-----END" line (post-encapsulation put the same label on the "-----END" line (post-encapsulation
boundary) as the corresponding "-----BEGIN" line. Parsers MAY boundary) as the corresponding "-----BEGIN" line. Parsers MAY
disregard the label on the "-----END" line instead of signaling an disregard the label on the "-----END" line instead of signaling an
error if there is a label mismatch. error if there is a label mismatch.
The label type implies that the encoded data follows the specified The label type implies that the encoded data follows the specified
syntax. Parsers MUST handle non-conforming data gracefully. syntax. Parsers MUST handle non-conforming data gracefully.
However, not all parsers or generators prior to this Internet-Draft However, not all parsers or generators prior to this Internet-Draft
behave consistently. A conforming parser MAY interpret the contents behave consistently. A conforming parser MAY interpret the contents
as another label type, but ought to be aware of the security as another label type, but ought to be aware of the security
implications discussed in the Security Considerations section. implications discussed in the Security Considerations section.
Unlike PEM encoding, OpenPGP ASCII armor, and OpenSSH key file Unlike legacy PEM encoding [RFC1421], OpenPGP ASCII armor, and the
format, PKIX text encoding does NOT define or permit attributes to be OpenSSH key file format, PKIX text encoding does NOT define or permit
encoded alongside the PKIX or CMS data. Whitespace MAY appear attributes to be encoded alongside the PKIX or CMS data. Whitespace
between the pre-encapsulation boundary and the base64, but generators MAY appear between the pre-encapsulation boundary and the base64, but
SHOULD NOT emit such whitespace. generators SHOULD NOT emit such whitespace.
Files MAY contain multiple instances of the text encoded Files MAY contain multiple PKIX text encoding instances. This is
representation. This is used, for example, when a file contains used, for example, when a file contains several certificates.
several certificates. Whether the instances are ordered or unordered Whether the instances are ordered or unordered depends on the
depends on the context. context.
Generators MUST wrap the base64 encoded lines so that each line Generators MUST wrap the base64 encoded lines so that each line
consists of exactly 64 characters except for the final line which consists of exactly 64 characters except for the final line which
will encode as much data is left (within the 64 character line will encode the remainder of the data (within the 64 character line
boundary). Parsers MAY handle other line sizes. These requirements boundary). Parsers MAY handle other line sizes. These requirements
are consistent with PEM [RFC1421]. are consistent with PEM [RFC1421].
3. ABNF 3. ABNF
The ABNF of the PKIX text encoding is: The ABNF of the PKIX text encoding is:
pkixmsg ::= preeb pkixmsg ::= preeb
*eolWSP *eolWSP
base64text base64text
posteb posteb
preeb ::= "-----BEGIN " label "-----" eol preeb ::= "-----BEGIN " label "-----" eol
posteb ::= "-----END " label "-----" eol posteb ::= "-----END " label "-----" eol
base64char ::= ALPHA / DIGIT / "+" / "/" base64char ::= ALPHA / DIGIT / "+" / "/"
base64pad ::= "=" base64pad ::= "="
base64line ::= 1*base64char eol base64line ::= 1*base64char eol
base64finl ::= *base64char *2base64pad eol ; implies that: base64finl ::= *base64char (base64pad eol base64pad /
; ...AB= <CRLF> = <CRLF> *2base64pad) eol
; is invalid. not sure ; ...AB= <CRLF> = <CRLF> is not good, but is valid
; if this is a good idea
base64text ::= *base64line base64finl base64text ::= *base64line base64finl
; we could also use <encbinbody> from RFC 1421, ; we could also use <encbinbody> from RFC 1421, which requires
; which requires 16 groups of 4 chars, which means 64 chars ; 16 groups of 4 chars, which means exactly 64 chars per
; exactly per line, except the final line ; line, except the final line, but this is more accurate
labelchar ::= %x21-2C / %x2E-%7E ; any printable character, labelchar ::= %x21-2C / %x2E-%7E ; any printable character,
; except hyphen ; except hyphen
label ::= labelchar *(labelchar / labelchar "-" / SP) labelchar label ::= labelchar *(labelchar / labelchar "-" / SP) labelchar
eol ::= CRLF / CR / LF eol ::= CRLF / CR / LF
eolWSP ::= WSP / CR / LF ; compare with LWSP eolWSP ::= WSP / CR / LF ; compare with LWSP
Figure 1: ABNF Figure 1: ABNF

strictbase64text

strictbase64finl ::= *15(4base64char) (4base64char / 3base64char

base64fullline ::= 64base64char eol
strictbase64text ::= *base64fullline strictbase64finl

4. Text Encoding of PKIX Certificates 4. Text Encoding of PKIX Certificates
4.1. Encoding 4.1. Encoding
PKIX certificates are encoded using the "CERTIFICATE" label. The PKIX certificates are encoded using the "CERTIFICATE" label. The
encoded data MUST be a DER encoded ASN.1 "Certificate" structure as encoded data MUST be a DER encoded ASN.1 "Certificate" structure as
described in section 4 of [RFC5280]. described in section 4 of [RFC5280].

4.2. Explanatory Text 4.2. Explanatory Text
Many tools are known to emit explanatory text before the BEGIN and Many tools are known to emit explanatory text before the BEGIN and
after the END labels for PKIX certificates, more than any other type. after the END lines for PKIX certificates, more than any other type.
If emitted, such text SHOULD be related to the certificate, such as If emitted, such text SHOULD be related to the certificate, such as
providing a textual representation of key data elements in the providing a textual representation of key data elements in the
certificate. certificate.

4.3. File Extension 4.3. File Extension
Although text encodings of PKIX structures can occur anywhere, many Although text encodings of PKIX structures can occur anywhere, many
tools are known to offer an option to encode PKIX structures in this tools are known to offer an option to encode PKIX structures in this
text encoding. To promote interoperability and to separate DER text encoding. To promote interoperability and to separate DER
encodings from text encodings, This Internet-Draft RECOMMENDS that encodings from text encodings, This Internet-Draft RECOMMENDS that
the extension ".crt" be used for this text encoding. Implementations the extension ".crt" be used for this text encoding. Implementations
should be aware that in spite of this recommendation, many tools should be aware that in spite of this recommendation, many tools
still default to encode certificates in this text encoding with the still default to encode certificates in this text encoding with the

12. Non-Conforming Examples

label variants described earlier in this document. As discussed
earlier, supporting these are not required and sometimes discouraged.
Still, they can be useful for interoperability testing and for easy
reference.

13. Security Considerations 12. Security Considerations
Data in this format often originates from untrusted sources, thus Data in this format often originates from untrusted sources, thus
parsers must be prepared to handle unexpected data without causing parsers must be prepared to handle unexpected data without causing
security vulnerabilities. security vulnerabilities.
Ambiguities are introduced by having more than one canonical encoding Ambiguities are introduced by having more than one canonical encoding
of the same data. The first ambiguity is introduced by permitting of the same data. The first ambiguity is introduced by permitting
the text encoded representation instead of the binary DER encoding, the text encoded representation instead of the binary DER encoding,
but further ambiguities arise when multiple labels are treated as but further ambiguities arise when multiple labels are treated as
similar. Variations of whitespace and non-base64 alphabetic similar. Variations of whitespace and non-base64 alphabetic
characters can create further ambiguities. Implementations that rely characters can create further ambiguities. Implementations that rely
on canonical representation or the ability to fingerprint a on canonical representation or the ability to fingerprint a
particular data format need to understand that this Internet-Draft particular data format need to understand that this Internet-Draft
does not define canonical encodings. If canonical encodings are does not define canonical encodings. If canonical encodings are
desired, the encoded structure must be decoded and processed into a desired, the encoded structure must be decoded and processed into a
canonical form (namely, DER encoding). Data encoding ambiguities canonical form (namely, DER encoding). Data encoding ambiguities
also create opportunities for side channels. also create opportunities for side channels.

Editorial Comments Appendix A. Non-Conforming Examples
[DP1] S.L.: Non-alphabetic characters is too broad. This section contains examples for the non-recommended label variants
Characters such as "+", "/", and "=" are valid base64; described earlier in this document. As discussed earlier, supporting
characters such as "-" and "_" are alternate base64 these are not required and sometimes discouraged. Still, they can be
characters but are not used in this specification. In useful for interoperability testing and for easy reference.
any event, any non-whitespace characters will cause
existing implementations to fail.
